ticket.title: Route to root of a namespace
ticket.original-body:
In Rails 2.3.x, you could do the following:
@@@ ruby map.namespace :admin do |admin| admin.root :controller => "admin" end @@@
It appears this functionality is missing in the Rails 3 router. Neither of the following match /admin:
@@@ ruby namespace :admin do root :to => 'admin#index' match '' => 'admin#index' end @@@

version.title: Route to root of a namespace

version.body:
This does actually work in the new DSL, however you have to explicitly set the namespace in the `:to`
In rails 2 if you had an Admin::Posts controller the following would have worked:
# http://localhost:3000/admin map.namespace :admin do |admin| admin.root :controller => 'posts' end
And the admin.root automagically picked up the namespace context. To do the same in the new routing, the following examples work:
# http://localhost:3000/admin namespace :admin do root :to => "admin/posts#index" end
# http://localhost:3000/admin namespace :admin do root :to => "Admin::Posts#index" end
version.body-html:

In rails 2 if you had an Admin::Posts controller the following would have worked:

# http://localhost:3000/admin
map.namespace :admin do |admin|
  admin.root :controller => 'posts'
end

And the admin.root automagically picked up the namespace context. To do the same in the new routing, the following examples work:

# http://localhost:3000/admin
namespace :admin do
  root :to => "admin/posts#index"
end

# http://localhost:3000/admin
namespace :admin do
  root :to => "Admin::Posts#index"
end

version.body: Is there any reason we should need to explicitly set the namespace in the :to when we're within the namespace block? Seems like it should know about the namespace context and avoid duplication.
